ygData.msgSnippet: ... Yes, with PUT, apart from naming the resource, the client should also be submitting a representation, and as Julian pointed out, a client who does not know

>
>
> Since the PUT is creating a new resource corresponding to the  
> provided URL (/destinationObject) it seems like a valid use of PUT  
> to me. Is the problem the fact that the PUT request is not providing  
> a representation for the resource (eg an XML document), but is only  
> providing a URL to the representation (via the x-amz-copy-source  
> header)?

Yes, with PUT, apart from naming the resource, the client should also  
be submitting a representation, and as Julian pointed out, a client  
who does not know this extension would end up creating empty resources.

Subbu
